Lynch v. Sprague, 372 Mass. 169 (1977) (.raw_text: Lynch v. Sprague, 372 Mass. 169 (1977) (recognizing duty owed to invitees by possessor of land).
Lynch v. Sprague, 372 Mass. 169 (1977) (.proposition: - Lynch v. Sprague, 372 Mass. 169 (1977) (recognizing duty owed to invitees by possessor of land).
Lynch v. Sprague, 372 Mass. 169 (1977) (.case_name: Cappadona v. Riverside 400 Function Room, Inc.
Lynch v. Sprague, 372 Mass. 169 (1977) (.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is about appellate review of interlocutory orders and the use of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court’s extraordinary powers under G.L. c. 211, § 3. It does not discuss premises liability, invitees, or the duty of a possessor of land. Therefore, it does not support the proposition that Lynch v. Sprague recognizes a duty owed to invitees by a possessor of land; in fact, the case excerpted is not Lynch v. Sprague at all but Cappadona-related litigation.
Lynch v. Sprague, 372 Mass. 169 (1977) (.relevant_excerpt: Interlocutory orders cannot be presented for appellate review, absent special authorization, until the entire case is ripe for review. Kargman v. Superior Court, supra. Rollins Environmental Servs. Inc. v. Superior Court, supra at 178. Giacobbe v. First Coolidge Corp., 367 Mass. 309, 312-313 (1975). This rule stems from the burdensome nature of piecemeal appellate review. Giacobbe, supra.

Rogers v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea C.raw_text: Rogers v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co., 371 Mass. 630 (1976) (constructive notice and foreseeability; premises liability principles).
Rogers v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea C.proposition: - Rogers v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co., 371 Mass. 630 (1976) (constructive notice and foreseeability; premises liability principles).
Rogers v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea C.support_reasoning: The proposition attributes to Rogers v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co. premises-liability principles about constructive notice and foreseeability, but the quoted opinion is not Rogers; it is Alholm v. Wareham (a Route 25 multicar-accident case) dealing with causation, nuisance, municipal liability, and directed verdict standards. It does not involve a store owner, transitory hazards, or constructive notice on premises, nor does it analyze foreseeability in the premises-liability sense. Therefore, this opinion does not support the stated proposition about Rogers and premises liability.
Rogers v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea C.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that, while there was evidence from which the jury could find that the town was maintaining a public nuisance and that the town was negligent in its maintenance of the dump, there was no evidence on which a jury could rationally base a conclusion that the smoke from the dump was causally related to the accident… The plaintiffs had the burden of proving that the alleged nuisance or negligence was the proximate cause of their injuries.”

Crowell v. Best Buy, 444 Mass. 27 (2005).raw_text: Crowell v. Best Buy, 444 Mass. 27 (2005) (store’s obligations to customers; notice issues).
Crowell v. Best Buy, 444 Mass. 27 (2005).proposition: - Crowell v. Best Buy, 444 Mass. 27 (2005) (store’s obligations to customers; notice issues).
Crowell v. Best Buy, 444 Mass. 27 (2005).support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Crowell v. Best Buy; it is a Massachusetts SJC decision concerning the Commonwealth’s petition to commit Wayne Chapman as a sexually dangerous person under G.L. c. 123A. It discusses collateral estoppel, due process, and standards for present sexual dangerousness, not premises liability, store obligations to customers, or notice issues. Therefore, this case does not support the proposition regarding store obligations and notice in Crowell v. Best Buy.
Crowell v. Best Buy, 444 Mass. 27 (2005).relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the doctrine of collateral estoppel does not bar the Commonwealth’s petition, that the petition set forth a sufficient factual basis to support the Commonwealth’s allegation of present sexual dangerousness, and that the judge prematurely dismissed the petition.”

Miller v. Winston Club, Inc., 22 Mass. A.raw_text: Miller v. Winston Club, Inc., 22 Mass. App. Ct. 570 (1986) (employer/possessor responsibilities; duty to protect invitees).
Miller v. Winston Club, Inc., 22 Mass. A.proposition: - Miller v. Winston Club, Inc., 22 Mass. App. Ct. 570 (1986) (employer/possessor responsibilities; duty to protect invitees).
Miller v. Winston Club, Inc., 22 Mass. A.case_name: Reilly v. Local 589, Amalgamated Transit Union
Miller v. Winston Club, Inc., 22 Mass. A.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns union fair-representation duties, arbitration of employment grievances, and apportionment of damages between an employer (MBTA) and a union under Bowen and Vaca. It does not deal with premises liability, duties of possessors of land, or an employer/possessor’s duty to protect invitees. The citation as authority on “employer/possessor responsibilities; duty to protect invitees” is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the case’s holding or reasoning.
Miller v. Winston Club, Inc., 22 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: “The question reported by Judge No. 7 in the MBTA’s 1981 case essentially raised the question whether, in a case subject to G. L. c. 150C, apportionment of the damages determined in an arbitrator’s award (under a collective bargaining agreement) as due from an employer may be imposed upon a union under the principles discussed in the Bowen case, 459 U.S. 212 (1983). We answer the question in general in the affirmative.”

Kershaw v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 33 Mass. A.raw_text: Kershaw v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 33 Mass. App. Ct. 751 (1992) (notice of dangerous condition; time factor).
Kershaw v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 33 Mass. A.proposition: - Kershaw v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 33 Mass. App. Ct. 751 (1992) (notice of dangerous condition; time factor).
Kershaw v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 33 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Kershaw v. Stop & Shop, Inc. at all; it is Hodge v. Klug, a landlord-tenant/summary process case concerning G.L. c. 239, § 8A, amendment of counterclaims, and tenant status, not notice of a dangerous condition or time-on-floor issues in premises liability. Because the case excerpted does not address notice of dangerous conditions or the time factor relevant to slip-and-fall or similar claims, it cannot support the stated proposition about Kershaw v. Stop & Shop. The citation is therefore mismatched to the content provided.
Kershaw v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 33 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: "Throughout this case, Klug has attempted to manipulate the summary process procedure and has misused statutory and regulatory protections for tenants in rental housing.... To effectuate the intent that summary process be expeditious and to deter dilatory manipulation of summary process procedure, we are of opinion that parties generally should be limited, upon appeal to the Superior Court under G.L.c. 239, § 5, to the defenses and counterclaims asserted in the District Court or Housing Court."

Boston & Maine R.R. v. Kent, 61 Mass. (7.raw_text: Boston & Maine R.R. v. Kent, 61 Mass. (7 Cush.) 261 (1851) (general negligence principles).
Boston & Maine R.R. v. Kent, 61 Mass. (7.proposition: - Boston & Maine R.R. v. Kent, 61 Mass. (7 Cush.) 261 (1851) (general negligence principles).
Boston & Maine R.R. v. Kent, 61 Mass. (7.support_reasoning: The opinion is about statutory construction and procedural requirements for poor debtors’ notices in an action on a prison-limits bond. It does not articulate or apply general negligence principles, nor does it involve a negligence cause of action, duties of care, or standards of reasonable conduct. Citing this case for general negligence principles is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the text of the opinion.
Boston & Maine R.R. v. Kent, 61 Mass. (7.relevant_excerpt: "For these reasons, without considering the other questions presented by the statement of facts, and argued by counsel, the court are very clearly of the opinion, that the notice of the 22d of March was invalid, because it was served before the expiration of seven days from the service of the previous notice. Judgment for the plaintiff."
